ul.li: Tutorial: build your first GacUI application.

topic.p: If you don't need runtime reflection on C++ classes, it is recommended to add VCZH_DEBUG_NO_REFLECTION to preprocessor definitions. By doing this, unnecessary code are eliminated, which significantly reduces both executable size and object sizes.

topic.title: VlppWorkflowLibrary.h and VlppWorkflowLibrary.cpp
topic.p:
They are needed for using Workflow.
Predefined libraries for Workflow script.
Helper functions for C++ code that generated from Workflow script.

topic.title: VlppWorkflowRuntime.h and VlppWorkflowRuntime.cpp
topic.p: They are needed for executing compiled binaries from Workflow script.

There are 2 ways to run Workflow script:
Generate C++ code from Workflow script, and add them to your project. This is recommended especially for running GacUI applications.
Load compiled binaries from Workflow script and run on-the-fly.

topic.title: VlppWorkflowCompiler.h and VlppWorkflowCompiler.cpp
topic.p: They are needed for compiling Workflow script.
There is no IO or other data exchange functionalities in predefined libraries. In order to make Workflow script works, usually you need to provide your own API to your script.

Typically, this is done by writing reflectable C++ class, loading type information and then running the compiler in the same process. And then you get a binary from compiled scripts, all classes defined in scripts are accessible. You can use VlppReflection to run classes in scripts.
The Workflow compiler can also generate C++ code. Using generated C++ code directly is always highly recommended when possible.
